item.title: Head of Russia’s Antidoping Agency Was Involved in 2014 Doping Scheme, Whistle-Blower Claims
item.content:encoded: The accusation surfaced as Russia tries to re-establish its Olympics eligibility.

item.title: Justices Strike Down Trump’s Tariffs
item.content:encoded: President Trump is the first to invoke the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 to set tariffs on imported goods from more than 100 countries.

item.title: Former Prince Andrew’s Arrest Upends Royal Family’s Effort to Move Past His Scandal
item.content:encoded: King Charles III’s family, long rocked by infighting and grievous losses, is facing what could be the gravest threat to its moral authority in more than a generation.

item.title: Why the United States Is Seeing an Ongoing Tourism Slump
item.content:encoded: Last year, the U.S. was the only major destination to see a decline in international travelers. With increased scrutiny at the border, ICE violence and unpredictable policies, the new year isn’t looking better.

item.title: Why the United States Is Seeing an Ongoing Tourism Slump
item.content:encoded: Last year, the U.S. was the only major destination to see a decline in international travelers. With increased scrutiny at the border, ICE violence and unpredictable policies, the new year isn’t looking better.

item.title: Some Reese’s Treats Drop the Milk Chocolate. Mr. Reese Disapproves.
item.content:encoded: With cocoa prices high, Hershey’s has changed some of its candy recipes. The grandson of the man who invented of the original Peanut Butter Cup said he was “embarrassed.”

item.title: Eric Dane, McSteamy on ‘Grey’s Anatomy,’ Dies at 53 After Battling ALS
item.content:encoded: His breakout role came in 2006 as the handsome Dr. Mark Sloan, nicknamed McSteamy, the head of plastic surgery at a Seattle hospital. He died 10 months after announcing his A.L.S. diagnosis.

item.title: A Cancer Detection Test Fails in Major Study
item.content:encoded: A closely watched clinical trial in Britain that screened blood for early detection of cancer did not show a reduction in later stages of the disease.

item.title: U.S. Economy Grew Modestly at End of 2025
item.content:encoded: Gross domestic product expanded at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the last quarter of the year, hit by the effects of the government shutdown.

item.title: U.S. Economy Grew Modestly at End of 2025
item.content:encoded: Gross domestic product expanded at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the last quarter of the year, hit by the effects of the government shutdown.

item.title: Who Has the Power in Trump’s White House?
item.content:encoded: The Atlantic staff writers Ashley Parker and Michael Scherer explain how Trump’s White House works.

item.title: A New U.S. Blockade Is Strangling Cuba
item.content:encoded: An analysis of ship movements shows that the Trump administration is isolating the island at one of its most vulnerable moments.

item.title: Last Group of Striking N.Y.C. Nurses Reaches Tentative Deal With Hospital
item.content:encoded: The agreement with NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital will still need to be ratified by rank-and-file members.

item.title: Can an A.I. Productivity Boom Clear a Path for More Rate Cuts? Trump’s Fed Pick Thinks So.
item.content:encoded: As Federal Reserve chair, Kevin M. Warsh may face a tough task persuading his colleagues to lower borrowing costs because of potential productivity gains.

item.title: Can an A.I. Productivity Boom Clear a Path for More Rate Cuts? Trump’s Fed Pick Thinks So.
item.content:encoded: As Federal Reserve chair, Kevin M. Warsh may face a tough task persuading his colleagues to lower borrowing costs because of potential productivity gains.

item.title: British Police Search Mansion Used by Former Prince Andrew
item.content:encoded: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, who is being investigated on suspicion of misconduct in public office, was released after an arrest that plunged the British royal family into crisis.

item.title: Is Blue Owl Private Credit’s ‘Canary in the Coal Mine’?
item.content:encoded: Steep declines in the shares of private lenders, after a major fund changed how investors can withdraw money, have sparked worries about more trouble to come.

item.title: Long Before ‘The Pitt,’ There Was the Freedom House
item.content:encoded: Freedom House Ambulance Service in Pittsburgh, a pioneer in emergency care, was largely forgotten. Now, members of Congress want to honor it.

item.title: A Royal Arrest
item.content:encoded: We look at the case of Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor.

item.title: Trump and Indonesia Sign Trade Deal, Locking in 19% Tariffs
item.content:encoded: The countries made official an agreement reached last year, with Indonesia avoiding a higher tariff and committing to cooperate on export controls.

item.title: MAHA Moms Turn Against Trump, and More States Rush to Limit Transgender Rights
item.content:encoded: Plus, your Friday news quiz.

item.title: Another Winter Storm Could Hit the Northeast This Weekend
item.content:encoded: There’s a lot of hype, but not a lot of certainty among forecasters yet. Here are three scenarios to watch.

item.title: How China Is Stoking Fear About Travel to Japan
item.content:encoded: From earthquake warnings to bear attack alerts, Beijing is deploying a campaign of exaggeration and disinformation to punish Tokyo’s support for Taiwan.

item.title: Mixed Signals Churn Stock Market Despite Recent Highs
item.content:encoded: Major indexes have mostly been treading water for months, as investors’ exuberance for artificial intelligence wears off.

item.title: Mixed Signals Churn Stock Market Despite Recent Highs
item.content:encoded: Major indexes have mostly been treading water for months, as investors’ exuberance for artificial intelligence wears off.

item.title: Was Anyone at Fault in Sierra Nevada Avalanche Deaths?
item.content:encoded: Few laws govern backcountry skiing in California. Experts say that people engage in the sport at their own risk, but guides have responsibilities to keep clients safe.

item.title: The 2028 Democratic Presidential Contenders, Ranked by Nate Silver
item.content:encoded: On the lookout for electoral overperformers.

item.title: South Texas Democrats Will Steer Party’s Direction, Left or Center
item.content:encoded: Like many Democratic primaries, the fight for the right to challenge a Republican House member in the Rio Grande Valley comes down to a choice, shift left or choose the party’s favorite for November.

item.title: A Makeup Ban in Syria for Women in Government and Public Sector Stirs Outrage
item.content:encoded: A provincial governor wants to prohibit women in government and public sector jobs from wearing makeup, stirring outrage and many, many memes.

item.title: What Curling Tells Us About the Mystery of Ice
item.content:encoded: Scientists are still discovering new theories on why ice is slippery. Our meteorologist Judson Jones and multimedia editor Joel Eastwood go curling to see how these theories could help Olympians achieve gold medals.

item.title: An Enemy’s Fall Frees Up South Korea’s Leader. Now Comes the Tough Part.
item.content:encoded: President Lee Jae Myung gained legitimacy from his predecessor’s conviction​. But South Korea’s political polarization is caustic, and could get worse.

item.title: He Was a Climate Activist. One Day, the F.B.I. Came Knocking.
item.content:encoded: As the Trump administration cracks down on climate change activism, members of environmental groups like Extinction Rebellion fear they are being targeted.

item.title: Stephen Colbert Balks at Trump’s Board of Peace
item.content:encoded: “The Late Show” host called the group “kind of like the U.N., except instead of passing binding resolutions, you pass a greasy bag of money to Donald Trump.”

item.title: Ukrainian Women Tell Their Stories of Sexual Violence by Russian Soldiers
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of Ukrainian women and girls have reported sexual violence by Russian troops during the four-year war in Ukraine.

item.title: Two Sisters Died in Tahoe Area Avalanche During Trek With Friends
item.content:encoded: Families and friends of the women, many from the Bay Area, confirmed their identities. The women went on regular trips to the Tahoe region and were experienced skiers, the families said.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Release Files on Aliens and U.F.O.s
item.content:encoded: President Trump had lashed out at former President Barack Obama earlier Thursday for telling a podcaster that aliens were real.

item.title: How The Times Made Judgment Calls on Covering the Arrest
item.content:encoded: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor was arrested on suspicion of misconduct in public office, then released hours later. Two Times reporters explain how they are covering the unprecedented moment.

item.title: Venezuela Passes Amnesty Bill Denounced by Some as ‘Unjust’
item.content:encoded: The bill may bring the release of hundreds of political prisoners. But many critics say the legislation, passed after major pressure from the Trump administration, raises concerns.

item.title: Blue Owl Capital Sets Off New Fears About the Private Credit Industry
item.content:encoded: The lender’s announcement that investors will no longer be able to ask for a set amount of money back from its funds prompted worries about the private credit industry.

item.title: Trump Has a Head-Spinning Day, but Republicans Want Him to Focus
item.content:encoded: President Trump’s advisers want him to lock down a message on the economy that will resonate ahead of the midterms. But Mr. Trump is never one to stay on message.

item.title: With ‘Tremendous’ Deals at Stake, Trump Is Bringing Russia in From the Cold
item.content:encoded: Since President Trump took office more than a year ago, the Kremlin has dangled possible investments in front of the famously transactional leader. The message is starting to resonate with investors.

item.title: Trump Administration Uses ‘Equal Time’ Rule to Reshape Late-Night TV
item.content:encoded: The F.C.C. is using the “equal time” provision to take aim at hosts like Stephen Colbert. The impact could reshape how talk shows handle politics.

item.title: Labor Secretary’s Husband Barred From Department Premises After Reports of Sexual Assaults
item.content:encoded: At least two female staff members said Dr. Shawn DeRemer had touched them inappropriately at the agency in Washington.

item.title: In 2025, Trade Deficit in Goods Reached Record High
item.content:encoded: Data released Thursday by the Census Bureau showed the overall trade deficit with the world narrowed, the result of an expanding trade surplus in services. The trade deficit in goods was the highest on record.

item.title: Bill Gates Cancels Speech in India Amid Epstein Controversy
item.content:encoded: The philanthropist made the announcement on Thursday, after having earlier confirmed his participation in a prominent artificial intelligence summit in India.

item.title: Doing Your Taxes? We Want to Hear From You.
item.content:encoded: The New York Times is looking to speak to Americans about how the most recent tax cuts are affecting their pocketbooks.

item.title: Donald J. Trump International Airport? The President’s Company Trademarked It.
item.content:encoded: The Trump organization said the move was necessary to protect the brand as Florida prepares to rename an airport after the president.

item.title: Trump Mulls a North American Trade Pact Without Canada
item.content:encoded: U.S. officials are threatening major changes to a trade agreement with Mexico and Canada that could upend the way business is done and leave Canada on the outs.

item.title: Walmart Expects Growth Streak to Continue as New Chief Takes Over
item.content:encoded: Shoppers are turning to Walmart to stretch their dollars, but an uncertain economy and trade tensions will test the retailer’s new executive team.

item.title: Jittery Markets Seek an Iran ‘Off-Ramp’
item.content:encoded: Oil prices spiked and stocks fell as tensions between Washington and Tehran unnerved investors.

item.title: Uber Moves to Enact Stricter Background Checks for Drivers
item.content:encoded: The New York Times revealed in December that the ride-hailing giant approved drivers with many types of criminal convictions, including violent felonies.

item.title: Ring’s Founder Knows You Hated That Super Bowl Ad
item.content:encoded: Since the commercial aired, Jamie Siminoff has been trying to quell an outcry over privacy concerns with his doorbell cameras.

item.title: Money Talks as India Searches for Its Place in Global A.I.
item.content:encoded: Narendra Modi, the prime minister, convened foreign leaders, the richest Silicon Valley companies and thousands of Indian entrepreneurs for a week of deal making.

item.title: Stock Slide and Slow Sales: What’s Happening in China’s E.V. Market?
item.content:encoded: Investors are selling shares of Chinese E.V. companies, concerned that intensifying competition and shorter production cycles mean the years of easy growth are over.

item.title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
item.content:encoded: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.

item.title: The Sleepy Market for Japanese Government Bonds Is Now a ‘Battlefield’
item.content:encoded: Trading of Japanese government bonds, long considered moribund, is roaring back to life as fears of the country’s debt have sent yields surging.

item.title: Workplace Inspections by OSHA Dropped Over a Six-Month Period of 2025
item.content:encoded: Labor advocates worry that the Trump administration is relaxing oversight of companies and increasing the potential for serious injuries and deaths.

item.title: F.D.A. Reverses Decision and Agrees to Review Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
item.content:encoded: Moderna held further discussions with regulators and announced that the agency would accept the company’s application for approval of its flu vaccine that uses mRNA technology.

item.title: Etsy Sells Depop, a Secondhand Clothing App Popular With Gen Z, to eBay
item.content:encoded: The $1.2 billion deal comes as eBay looks to expand its appeal among younger users.

item.title: Edison Will Reduce Executive Bonuses as a Result of the Eaton Fire
item.content:encoded: Southern California Edison had said its electrical equipment most likely caused the blaze, which destroyed much of Altadena, a Los Angeles suburb.

item.title: The New York Times Wins 3 Polk Awards
item.content:encoded: The Times was honored for its coverage of President Trump, the abuse of housekeepers and nannies in Saudi Arabia and brutality in New York prisons.

item.title: Fed Minutes Show No Rush to Restart Rate Cuts
item.content:encoded: Barring a rapid deterioration in the labor market or a significant cooling of inflation, the Federal Reserve appears poised for an extended hold.

item.title: What Do A.I. Chatbots Discuss Among Themselves? We Sent One to Find Out.
item.content:encoded: We interviewed our bot about what it learned on Moltbook, the A.I.-only social network.

item.title: From 2001: Rose Freedman, Last Survivor of Triangle Fire, Dies at 107
item.content:encoded: She escaped the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911, in which 146 of her co-workers perished, and dedicated the rest of her life to worker safety.

item.title: Kentucky Derby Operator Accused of Regulatory ‘Freeloading’
item.content:encoded: The Horseracing Integrity and Safety Authority filed a complaint saying Churchill Downs Inc. is not paying its fair share to support inspections and testing.

item.title: Elon Musk’s xAI Gets $3 Billion Investment From Saudi-Backed A.I. Firm
item.content:encoded: Humain, which was created by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman last year, said it made the investment just before xAI was acquired by SpaceX, Mr. Musk’s rocket company.

item.title: How Crypto’s Lobbying Muscle May Save the Clarity Act
item.content:encoded: A market rout may have decimated the crypto industry. But its machine in Washington may power proposed regulation past concerned Democrats.

item.title: Uber Taking Steps to Expand Number of EV Chargers Near Its Drivers
item.content:encoded: The company said it would encourage companies that operated chargers to install them in neighborhoods where its drivers lived and work.

item.title: Trump Hails Japan’s First Batch of U.S. Investments
item.content:encoded: The deals, totaling $36 billion, were the first step in a $550 billion investment pledge aimed at securing tariff relief and sustaining U.S. relations.

item.title: Boneless Wings Are Still Wings, Judge Rules
item.content:encoded: A Chicago man filed a lawsuit in 2023 against Buffalo Wild Wings, arguing that it had engaged in false advertising of its boneless wings. A judge said the claim “has no meat on its bones.”

item.title: Goldman Sachs to Drop D.E.I. Criteria for Board Members
item.content:encoded: The move would be the Wall Street firm’s latest retreat from diversity mandates that its chief executive, David Solomon, had once made a priority.

item.title: White House Shrugs Off Lutnick’s Epstein Ties
item.content:encoded: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has acknowledged traveling to Jeffrey Epstein’s island and meeting him on another occasion.

item.title: Are you a medical provider who has worked in an ICE detention facility? We want to hear from you.
item.content:encoded: We want to get a better picture of what medical care for immigrants in detention is like.

item.title: Colbert Slams Trump Administration After CBS Pulls Talarico Interview
item.content:encoded: Stephen Colbert said he had to drop an interview with James Talarico from his Monday broadcast because of new F.C.C. guidance that targeted political interviews on late-night shows.

item.title: Bayer Agrees to Pay $7.25 Billion to Settle Roundup Lawsuits
item.content:encoded: The agreement, which still faces legal hurdles, would cover current and future claims that the weedkiller caused non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

item.title: Warner Bros. Discovery Restarts Deal Talks With Paramount
item.content:encoded: Paramount’s takeover bid was rejected in favor of Netflix, which wanted only the streaming and studio businesses. Paramount said it would pay more if negotiations were reopened.

item.title: GQ Names Adam Baidawi as Its Top Editor
item.content:encoded: Mr. Baidawi, 35, replaces the magazine’s longtime editor Will Welch. He says he wants the magazine to be a “North Star of masculinity.”

item.title: Paramount’s New Chance to Win Over Warner Bros. Discovery
item.content:encoded: The takeover battle took a new turn on Tuesday as Warner Bros. Discovery reopened talks with its rebuffed suitor. But big questions still remain.

item.title: Trump Sought Vast Budget Cuts. Congress Granted Few.
item.content:encoded: In a series of deals over the past three months, lawmakers rejected some of the president’s most aggressive attempts to whittle down the government.

item.title: With Niche Tech World References, Vibe Hopes Its Billboards Reach Start-Up Insiders
item.content:encoded: Billboards that wouldn’t make sense to people outside the tech industry have become common in the Bay Area. One company took the microtargeting game to another level.
